reporting-org.narrative: Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights Africa Trust

description.narrative: Millions of young people do not have access to appropriate, gender-responsive, quality SRHR education, information and services. This makes them vulnerable to unintended pregnancies, often followed by child marriage (CM). The Break Free! programme empowers adolescents and young people to make their own free and informed choices to speak out and have control over their SRH and lives. BF! is tackling root causes of gender inequality, unequal power relations and discriminatory social norms, systems, structures, policies and practices, supported by civil society and improved legislation. The project will be implemented between 2021 and 2025 by the Break Free! Consortium consisting of Plan International Netherlands, SAT and FAWE, technical partners KIT and RMT in collaboration with Dutch Embassies. It will be carried out in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Niger, Sudan and Zambia, in addition to a regional Pan-African component to sustain the country programmes.

The primary target group of the Break Free programme consists if girls and young women (GYW) aged 10 -24. To effectuate change in the lives of those GYW, the programme engages other stakeholders such as government, CSOs, parents and/or caretakers and the community at large in the 9 focus countries of Break Free!

The strategic programme objective of: adolescents exercise their right to live free from TP and CM, supported by civil society is contributing the above-defined impact. To achieve this strategic objective, CSOs, youth-led groups and networks will be strengthened to lobby and advocate for improved legislation and implementation to increase girls’ agency and to promote social norm change in favour of the prevention of CM/TP, and in some countries FGM/C. Although norm change takes time and the strategic objective is formulated under the ‘sphere of influence’ over which we do not have full control, the programme will report reduced prevalence of CM and TP for groups of girls in the programme locations, by 2025. The following three pathways of change lead towards the strategic programme objective.
Outcome 1: Adolescent girls at risk of CM/TP access quality and safe education, Outcome 2: Duty bearers and decision-makers develop, resource and implement laws and policies that respond to adolescents’ needs, and Outcome 3: Adolescents access quality SRHR information, education and services.
